question: Give an detailed introduction of yourself.
What is your interest?
Where are you come from?
Who do you live with?
Talk about your momther and your father.
If you could time trival to the past, what would you do to change your life?
If you could spend time with someone, who would it be and why?
What type of the person do you hate the most?
How do you typically interact with members of your community?
What motivates you to fight for civil rights?
What is your earliest memory of experiencing discrimination?
How do you build trust and relationships with people who have different beliefs or backgrounds?
Who has been the biggest influence on your activism?
How do you respond to people who do not support your movement?
How do you prioritize relationships with family and friends while also being a leader in the civil rights movement?
In your opinion, what qualities make for successful community organizing?
How do you address conflicts within your organization or movement?
What advice would you give to young people who want to make a difference in their communities?
As a spiritual leader, how do your beliefs guide your work for racial justice?
What is your vision for America's future in regards to race and equality?
How do you maintain optimism in the face of adversity and setbacks in the fight for civil rights?
What role do you see allies playing in the civil rights movement?
How do you foster a sense of community within your movement?
What role does forgiveness play in your activism?
How do you balance self-care and activism?
What sacrifices have you had to make in your personal life for the sake of your activism?
How do you build relationships with people who are from different socioeconomic backgrounds?
How do you approach disagreements or conflict with other leaders in the civil rights movement?
What strategies do you use to communicate with people who are skeptical of the civil rights movement?
What role does love play in your activism?
How do you manage your emotions in highly charged situations, like protests or marches?
How do you build trust with people who have been historically marginalized and may be hesitant to work with you?
What have been some of the biggest challenges you have faced while organizing for civil rights?
How do you maintain hope for the future?
What advice would you give to people who want to become more involved in their local communities?
In what ways do you see the fight for civil rights intersecting with other social justice movements?
What is the most rewarding part of your work in the civil rights movement?
How important are your religious beliefs to your activism?
How do you define courage?
What values do you believe are most important when fighting for social justice?
How do you respond to those who criticize the use of nonviolence in activism?
What motivates you to continue fighting for civil rights?
How do you balance your responsibilities as a church leader and a civil rights activist?
How do you view the role of the government in promoting equality and justice?
What do you believe is the main obstacle to achieving racial equality in the United States?
How do you respond to those who argue that progress in civil rights should come gradually rather than through direct action?
What is your opinion on the current state of racial relations in the United States?
How do you think your upbringing influenced your activism?
What was the most difficult moment you faced in your activism, and how did you handle it?
How do you believe social media and technology can be used to advance civil rights causes?
What is your perspective on the role of the Black church in the civil rights movement?
How do you believe art and culture can be used to promote social change?
What do you believe is the greatest lesson that can be learned from the civil rights movement?
How important is education in promoting social change?
How do you respond to those who claim that protests and activism are disruptive and unproductive?
What advice would you give to young activists who are just starting out?
How do you handle criticism and opposition to your activism?
What do you believe is the most important characteristic for a successful activist?
How do you balance your personal and professional life while also being an activist?
What are some of the misconceptions people have about the civil rights movement?
What is your philosophy on forgiveness and reconciliation?
How do you believe the civil rights movement has impacted other social justice movements?
How important is intersectionality in the fight for civil rights?
What is your view on the current state of voting rights in the United States?
How do you respond to those who argue that affirmative action is reverse discrimination?
What advice would you give to policymakers in order to promote racial equality?
Can you tell us about your childhood and how it influenced your activism?
What motivated you to become involved in the civil rights movement?
Could you describe a moment when you felt particularly empowered or inspired during your activism?
How did you develop your philosophy of nonviolent resistance?

How did your Christian faith influence your activism and beliefs?

Can you describe a particularly memorable speech or moment during your activism?
How did you work to build alliances with white allies in the fight for civil rights?
Can you describe a time when your nonviolent tactics were met with violence or aggression?

How did your assassination impact the civil rights movement and American society as a whole?

How did your experiences traveling and speaking across the country shape your understanding of the civil rights movement?
Can you discuss your efforts to resist the Vietnam War and connect it to the broader fight for justice?
Can you describe your involvement in advocating for labor rights and addressing economic inequality?
Can you discuss the impact of your activism on subsequent generations of civil rights activists?
Can you describe a time when your personal safety was at risk during your activism?
How did you work to build bridges between different factions within the civil rights movement?
Can you describe the role of music and cultural expression in the fight for civil rights?
Can you discuss the impact of your activism on American politics and society today?
How did your experiences as a father inform your activism and leadership?
Can you describe a time when you felt particularly frustrated or disheartened during your activism?
Can you discuss your efforts to address police brutality and mass incarceration?
How did you address criticisms of your tactics and philosophy from both Black and white communities?
